docs.text:
Welcome to Geomorphology

Exploring the dynamic landscape, landform evolution, and the processes shaping our Earth.

SCAN TO BROWSE

Welcome to the Geomorphology study portal. This site covers the fundamental concepts of landforms, Earth's surface processes, and the evolution of landscapes over time.

docs.title: Objective
docs.text: To provide a deep understanding of Geomorphology, the nature of landforms, and the physical processes that shape the Earth's surface through continuous interaction of geological and climatic forces.

docs.title: Introduction
docs.text: This unit serves as the foundational pillar for understanding Geomorphology. Before delving into advanced geomorphic modeling, it is imperative to grasp the core concepts of Earth's surface processes. In this unit, we explore the dynamic interaction between geological forces and climatic factors, mapping out how the landscape is continuously shaped and transformed over time.

docs.title: Learning Objectives
docs.text:
By the end of this unit, you should be able to:

  1. Define and Differentiate: Clearly distinguish between a 'Hazard' and a 'Disaster' using official international and national definitions.
  2. Classify Hazards: Categorize hazards into natural and manmade, and further into specific sub-types (geological, hydrological, etc.).
  3. Analyze Risk: Understand the Risk Equation (\(Risk = Hazard \times Vulnerability / Capacity\)) and its implications.
  4. Understand Key Mechanisms: Grasp the concepts of prevention, mitigation, and management as proactive measures.

docs.title: Unit Outline
docs.text:
• Concept of Hazards and Disasters: Official definitions and conceptual frameworks.
  • Natural and Manmade Hazards: Exploring the origins of hazards.
  • Types of Hazards: Detailed classification of specific hazards.
  • Concept of Vulnerability and Risk: The physics and sociology of disaster risk.
  • Prevention, Mitigation, and Management: The triad of risk reduction.

Study Resource

For a global perspective on these definitions, refer to the UNDRR Terminology on Disaster Risk Reduction.

docs.title: Nature and Scope of Geomorphology: The Science of Landforms
1. Introduction to Geomorphology
docs.text:
Geomorphology is the scientific study of the nature, origin, and evolution of landforms on the Earth's surface and the processes that shape them. The term is derived from three Greek words: Gē (Earth), morphē (form), and logos (discourse/study).

Landforms are the result of a dynamic interface between the Lithosphere, Hydrosphere, Atmosphere, and Biosphere. Geomorphologists seek to understand why the Earth looks the way it does and how landscapes change over time.

docs.title: 2. Fundamental Concepts in Geomorphology
docs.text: The modern study of geomorphology is built upon several core principles that guide our interpretation of the landscape.

docs.title: A. Principle of Uniformitarianism
docs.text: Proposed by James Hutton and popularized by Charles Lyell, the mantra is: "The present is the key to the past." It suggests that the physical processes acting today (erosion, deposition, plate tectonics) have operated throughout geologic time, though not always with the same intensity.

docs.title: B. Geomorphic Processes
docs.text:
Landforms are products of a complex interaction between two types of forces:

  1. Endogenetic Forces: Internal forces originating from within the Earth (volcanism, tectonics) that create "Primary Landforms" (mountains, plateaus).
  2. Exogenetic Forces: External forces originating from the atmosphere (weathering, wind, water) that wear down the primary landforms to create "Secondary Landforms."

docs.title: C. The Concept of Equilibrium
docs.text: Geomorphic systems tend to reach a state of dynamic equilibrium, where the input of material (e.g., tectonic uplift) and the output (e.g., erosion) are balanced, resulting in a stable landform over a specific timeframe.

docs.title: D. Geomorphic Thresholds
docs.text: A landscape may remain stable until a specific "threshold" is crossed (e.g., a massive storm or excessive slope steepening), causing a sudden and rapid change in the landform (e.g., a landslide).

docs.title: 3. The Scale of Geomorphology
docs.text:
Landforms are classified based on their size and the time required for their formation:

Order Scale Feature Examples First Order Global Continental masses and ocean basins Eurasia, Pacific Ocean Basin Second Order Regional Large structural units Himalayan Mountains, Deccan Plateau Third Order Local Individual landforms created by erosion/deposition Cirque, Sand Dune, River Meander

docs.title: 4. Schools of Geomorphic Thought
docs.text: Historically, two major paradigms dominated the field regarding how landscapes evolve:

docs.title: A. The Cycle of Erosion (William Morris Davis)
docs.text: Davis proposed that landscapes go through stages of Youth, Maturity, and Old Age. He argued that any landform is a function of: $$ \text{Landform} = f(\text{Structure, Process, Stage}) $$ Davis called this the "Trio of Geomorphology."

docs.title: B. Slope Replacement Model (Walther Penck)
docs.text: Penck challenged Davis's "Stage" concept. He argued that landforms are a result of the competition between the rate of uplift and the rate of degradation. If uplift is faster, slopes steepen; if degradation is faster, slopes flatten.

docs.title: 5. Modern Geomorphology
docs.text:
Today, the field has moved beyond simple descriptive models to:

  • Quantitative Geomorphology: Using mathematical modeling to predict erosion rates.
  • Climatic Geomorphology: Studying how different climates (Tropical, Arid, Glacial) produce unique landforms.
  • Applied Geomorphology: Using geomorphic knowledge to solve human problems, such as predicting landslides, managing river flooding, and coastal protection.

docs.title: Multiple Choice Questions
docs.text:
1. The term "Geomorphology" is derived from which language? Click to show Answer Correct Answer: Greek (Gē, morphē, logos)

  2. Who proposed the "Trio of Geomorphology" (Structure, Process, Stage)? Click to show Answer Correct Answer: William Morris Davis

  3. "The present is the key to the past" represents which principle? Click to show Answer Correct Answer: Principle of Uniformitarianism

  4. Ocean basins are considered landforms of which order? Click to show Answer Correct Answer: First Order

  5. Which forces are responsible for creating "Primary Landforms"? Click to show Answer Correct Answer: Endogenetic Forces

docs.title: Descriptive Questions
docs.text:
1. Describe the "Trio of Geomorphology" as proposed by W.M. Davis. Click to see Key Points

    • Structure: Rock type, folding, and faulting.
    • Process: The specific force acting on the rock (e.g., fluvial, glacial).
    • Stage/Time: The duration for which the process has been acting on the structure.

  2. Differentiate between Endogenetic and Exogenetic processes. Click to see Key Points

    • Endogenetic: Internal, constructive, creates relief (e.g., volcanism).
    • Exogenetic: External, destructive/gradational, levels relief (e.g., erosion).

docs.title: Endogenetic and Exogenetic Processes: Forces Shaping the Earth
1. Introduction: The Geomorphic Engine
docs.text:
The Earth's surface is under constant modification. These changes are driven by two types of forces: Endogenetic (Internal) and Exogenetic (External). While internal forces build the landscape by creating relief (mountains, trenches), external forces tear it down through erosion and weathering.

Geomorphology studies the "tug-of-war" between these two forces.

docs.title: 2. Endogenetic Processes (Constructive Forces)
docs.text: Endogenetic processes originate deep within the Earth's interior and are driven by thermal energy, radioactivity, and rotational forces.

docs.title: A. Diastrophism
docs.text:
This includes all processes that move, elevate, or build portions of the Earth's crust.

  • Orogenic Processes (Mountain Building): Horizontal movements that cause folding and faulting of the crust (e.g., Himalayas).
  • Epeirogenic Processes (Continental Building): Vertical movements causing the uplift or subsidence of large parts of the Earth's crust (e.g., the emergence of a coast).

docs.title: B. Volcanism
docs.text: The movement of molten rock (magma) onto or toward the Earth's surface. Constructive volcanism creates landforms like shield volcanoes, cinder cones, and plateaus (e.g., the Deccan Traps).

docs.title: C. Plate Tectonics
docs.text:
The theory that the Earth's lithosphere is divided into plates that move relative to each other.

  • Divergent Boundaries: Plates move apart (e.g., Mid-Atlantic Ridge).
  • Convergent Boundaries: Plates collide (e.g., Himalayan Orogeny).
  • Transform Boundaries: Plates slide past each other (e.g., San Andreas Fault).

docs.title: 3. Exogenetic Processes (Destructive Forces)
docs.text: Exogenetic processes act upon the Earth's surface and derive their energy from the Atmosphere (the Sun) and Gravity. They are primarily gradational forces, meaning they work to level the Earth's surface.

docs.title: A. Weathering
docs.text:
The mechanical disintegration and chemical decomposition of rocks in situ (without movement).

  • Physical Weathering: Freezing/thawing, pressure release.
  • Chemical Weathering: Oxidation, carbonation, hydration.
  • Biological Weathering: Roots growing in cracks, burrowing animals.

docs.title: B. Mass Wasting
docs.text: The downward movement of rock and soil under the direct influence of Gravity. It does not require a transporting medium like water, wind, or ice (e.g., landslides, rockfalls).

docs.title: C. Erosion and Deposition
docs.text:
The process of acquiring and transporting rock particles by a dynamic agent (water, ice, wind, waves).

  • Fluvial: Action of running water (rivers).
  • Aeolian: Action of wind.
  • Glacial: Action of moving ice.
  • Coastal: Action of waves and currents.

docs.title: 4. The Geomorphic Cycle
docs.text:
Exogenetic forces work toward Peneplanation—the reduction of the entire landmass to a nearly flat plain (peneplain) close to sea level. However, this is rarely achieved because endogenetic forces usually intervene by uplifting the land again.

Feature Endogenetic Exogenetic Energy Source Internal (Heat/Gravity) External (Solar/Gravity) Main Action Constructive (Relief-building) Destructive (Relief-leveling) Speed Often slow (Mountain building) Slow but continuous (Erosion) Examples Folding, Faulting, Volcanism Weathering, Erosion, Mass Wasting

docs.title: Multiple Choice Questions
docs.text:
1. Which process is responsible for "Mountain Building"? Click to show Answer Correct Answer: Orogenic Processes

  2. "Weathering" is an example of which type of force? Click to show Answer Correct Answer: Exogenetic Force

  3. What is the primary driving force behind Mass Wasting? Click to show Answer Correct Answer: Gravity

  4. The "Himalayas" were formed at what type of plate boundary? Click to show Answer Correct Answer: Convergent Boundary

  5. Wait is the ultimate result of continued exogenetic action? Click to show Answer Correct Answer: Peneplanation

docs.title: Descriptive Questions
docs.text:
1. Explain the difference between Orogenic and Epeirogenic movements. Click to see Key Points

    • Orogenic: Horizontal, focused on small areas, builds folded mountains.
    • Epeirogenic: Vertical, acts on large scales (continental), leads to uplift or subsidence.

  2. How does chemical weathering differ from physical weathering? Click to see Key Points

    • Physical: Disintegration into smaller pieces without changing chemical composition.
    • Chemical: Decomposition of minerals through chemical reactions, changing the rock's internal structure.

docs.title: Fluvial, Aeolian, and Glacial Landscapes: The Agents of Change
1. Introduction: Agents of Erosion and Deposition
docs.text: While endogenetic forces create high-relief landforms, agents of gradation (water, wind, ice) work continuously to reshape them. These agents perform three functions: Erosion, Transportation, and Deposition. Each agent creates a unique set of landforms depending on the climate and rock structure.

docs.title: 2. Fluvial Landscapes (Action of Running Water)
docs.text: Running water is the most significant geomorphic agent globally.

docs.title: A. Erosional Landforms
docs.text:
• V-Shaped Valleys: Formed by downward cutting in the youthful stage of a river.
  • Waterfalls and Rapids: Formed where a river flows over rocks of varying resistance.
  • Potholes: Circular depressions in the riverbed carved by swirling pebbles.

docs.title: B. Depositional Landforms
docs.text:
• Alluvial Fans: Fan-shaped deposits where a mountain stream enters a plain.
  • Floodplains: Flat areas adjacent to a river that are periodically submerged.
  • Deltas: Triangular deposits at the mouth of a river (e.g., Sundarbans Delta).

docs.title: 3. Aeolian Landscapes (Action of Wind)
docs.text: Wind is a dominant agent in arid and semi-arid regions where vegetation is sparse.

docs.title: A. Erosional Landforms
docs.text:
• Mushroom Rocks: Rocks with a narrow base and wide top, carved by sand-laden winds near the ground.
  • Deflation Hollows: Depressions in the desert floor created by the removal of loose sand.
  • Yardangs: Long, narrow ridges of rock parallel to the wind direction.

docs.title: B. Depositional Landforms
docs.text:
• Sand Dunes: Mounds of sand (e.g., Barchans, Longitudinal dunes).
  • Loess: Fine, wind-blown silt deposited far from its source (e.g., Loess Plateau in China).

docs.title: 4. Glacial Landscapes (Action of Moving Ice)
docs.text: Glaciers are "rivers of ice" that move under their own weight.

docs.title: A. Erosional Landforms
docs.text:
• U-Shaped Valleys (Glacial Troughs): Formed when a glacier widens and deepens a V-shaped valley.
  • Cirques: Bowl-shaped depressions at the head of a glacier.
  • Aretes: Sharp, knife-like ridges between two cirques.

docs.title: B. Depositional Landforms
docs.text:
• Moraines: Accumulations of dirt and rocks (till) deposited by a glacier.
  • Eskers: Long, winding ridges of sand and gravel deposited by sub-glacial streams.
  • Drumlins: Egg-shaped hills of glacial till.

docs.title: 5. Coastal Landscapes (Action of Waves)
docs.text: The interaction between land and sea creates dynamic coastal features.

docs.title: A. Erosional Landforms
docs.text:
• Cliffs and Wave-cut Platforms: Vertical rock faces and the flat benches at their base.
  • Sea Caves, Arches, and Stacks: Successive stages of erosional breakdown of a headland.

docs.title: B. Depositional Landforms
docs.text:
• Beaches: Accumulations of sand/shingle along the shore.
  • Spits and Bars: Narrow ridges of sand extending into the sea or connecting two headlands.

docs.title: Multiple Choice Questions
docs.text:
1. Which agent is responsible for creating "U-Shaped Valleys"? Click to show Answer Correct Answer: Glaciers

  2. A "Barchan" is a type of: Click to show Answer Correct Answer: Aeolian Sand Dune (Crescent-shaped)

  3. Which landform is formed at the mouth of a river as it enters the sea? Click to show Answer Correct Answer: Delta

  4. "Mushroom Rocks" are characteristic of which environment? Click to show Answer Correct Answer: Arid / Desert (Aeolian)

  5. "Moraines" are depositional features of: Click to show Answer Correct Answer: Glaciers

docs.title: Descriptive Questions
docs.text:
1. Explain the formation of a River Delta. Click to see Key Points

    • Occurs where a river meets a standing body of water (sea/lake).
    • The river's velocity drops to zero.
    • The load (sediment) is deposited.
    • Distributaries form as the river weaves through its own deposits.

  2. Differentiate between a V-shaped and a U-shaped valley. Click to see Key Points

    • V-shaped: Formed by vertical river erosion; steep sides and narrow bottom.
    • U-shaped: Formed by glacial scour; wide flat bottom and nearly vertical sides.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: Test your understanding of the foundational concepts of Geomorphology. This assessment covers the nature and scope of the field, endogenetic and exogenetic processes, landform classification, and the major geomorphic agents (Fluvial, Aeolian, Glacial).

docs.title: Part A: Multiple Choice Questions (MCQs)
docs.text: 1. The concept that "The present is the key to the past" is known as: Click to show Options A) Catastrophism B) Uniformitarianism C) Peneplanation D) Diastrophism Click to show Answer Correct Answer: B) Uniformitarianism  2. Which of the following is a "Second Order" landform? Click to show Options A) The Pacific Ocean Basin B) The Himalayan Mountain Range C) A River Delta D) A Sand Dune Click to show Answer Correct Answer: B) The Himalayan Mountain Range  3. W.M. Davis's "Trio of Geomorphology" consists of Structure, Process, and: Click to show Options A) Scale B) Climate C) Stage (Time) D) Slope Click to show Answer Correct Answer: C) Stage (Time)  4. Which force is primarily responsible for the creation of Fold Mountains? Click to show Options A) Exogenetic Forces B) Endogenetic Forces C) Weathering D) Denudation Click to show Answer Correct Answer: B) Endogenetic Forces (specifically Orogenic movements)  5. The process of rocks peeling away in layers due to thermal expansion is called: Click to show Options A) Carbonation B) Exfoliation C) Hydration D) Oxidation Click to show Answer Correct Answer: B) Exfoliation  6. V-shaped valleys are typically formed by the action of: Click to show Options A) Glaciers B) Wind C) Running Water (Fluvial) D) Waves Click to show Answer Correct Answer: C) Running Water (Fluvial)  7. "Mushroom Rocks" are erosional landforms created by: Click to show Options A) Rivers B) Wind (Aeolian) C) Glaciers D) Groundwater Click to show Answer Correct Answer: B) Wind (Aeolian)  8. Which landform is a bowl-shaped depression found at the head of a glacial valley? Click to show Options A) Cirque B) Esker C) Drumlin D) Moraine Click to show Answer Correct Answer: A) Cirque  9. The mechanical disintegration of rocks *in-situ* is termed as: Click to show Options A) Erosion B) Deposition C) Weathering D) Transportation Click to show Answer Correct Answer: C) Weathering  10. An "Ox-bow lake" is a feature of which stage of a river? Click to show Options A) Youthful Stage B) Mature/Old Stage C) Mountain Stage D) Deltaic Stage Click to show Answer Correct Answer: B) Mature/Old Stage (due to meandering)

docs.title: Part B: Descriptive Questions
docs.text: 1. Discuss the Principle of Uniformitarianism in Geomorphology. (click to see key points) Click to see Key Points Key Points: - **Origin:** Proposed by James Hutton (1785), popularized by Charles Lyell. - **Mantra:** "The present is the key to the past." - **Core Idea:** The same physical and chemical processes (erosion, sedimentation, tectonics) that operate today have operated throughout Earth's history. - **Significance:** Allows geomorphologists to interpret ancient landforms by observing modern ones.  2. Differentiate between Endogenetic and Exogenetic processes. (click to see key points) Click to see Key Points Key Points: - **Endogenetic:** Internal forces (Heat/Tectonics). Constructive. Create relief (Mountains, Trenches). - **Exogenetic:** External forces (Solar energy/Atmosphere). Destructive/Gradational. Level relief (Weathering, Erosion). - **Interaction:** Landscapes are the result of the balance between these two opposing forces.  3. Explain the different types of Weathering with examples. (click to see key points) Click to see Key Points Key Points: - **Physical:** Mechanical break (e.g., Frost wedging in cold climates, Exfoliation in deserts). - **Chemical:** Decomposition (e.g., Carbonation of limestone, Oxidation of iron-rich rocks). - **Biological:** Living roots/animals (e.g., Tree roots splitting rocks).  4. Describe the erosional and depositional landforms of Glaciers. (click to see key points) Click to see Key Points Key Points: - **Erosional:** U-shaped valleys, Cirques, Aretes, Hanging valleys. - **Depositional:** Moraines (Lateral, Terminal), Eskers (Sinuous ridges), Drumlins (Egg-shaped hills).

docs.title: Classification of Landforms: From Global to Local
1. Introduction: The Hierarchy of Landforms
docs.text: The Earth's surface is not a uniform sphere but a complex arrangement of features varying in size and origin. Geomorophologists classify these features into a hierarchy based on their geographic extent and the duration of their formation.

docs.title: First Order Landforms
docs.text:
These are the most fundamental features of the Earth's crust, formed by the original cooling of the Earth and early global tectonics.

  • Continental Platforms: The large landmasses of the Earth.
  • Ocean Basins: The deep depressions filled by the world's oceans.

docs.title: Second Order Landforms
docs.text:
These are large-scale features found on the continents or ocean floors, primarily created by Endogenetic forces (horizontal and vertical movements of the crust).

  • Mountains: High-elevation features created by folding or faulting (e.g., Alps, Andes).
  • Plateaus: Elevated flat lands (e.g., Tibetan Plateau).
  • Plains: Extensive flat or gently undulating lands (e.g., Great Plains).

docs.title: Third Order Landforms
docs.text:
These are smaller, localized features carved out of second-order landforms by Exogenetic forces (erosion and deposition).

  • Erosional Landforms: Canyons, cirques, meanders, and mushroom rocks.
  • Depositional Landforms: Deltas, moraines, sand dunes, and alluvial fans.

docs.title: 3. Structural vs. Denudational Landforms
docs.text: Landforms can also be classified based on the dominance of the force that shaped them:

docs.title: A. Structural Landforms
docs.text:
Influenced directly by the underlying rock structure (folding, faulting, or volcanism).

  • Fold Mountains: Created by the squeezing of rock layers.
  • Rift Valleys: Formed by the downward faulting of a crustal block (e.g., East African Rift).
  • Volcanic Cones: Built up by the accumulation of lava and ash.

docs.title: B. Denudational Landforms
docs.text:
Formed by the process of Denudation (weathering + erosion + mass wasting).

  • Residual Mountains: Mountains left behind after the surrounding area has been eroded (e.g., monadnocks).
  • Pediplains: Large, flat areas formed by the retreat of mountain slopes in arid regions.

docs.title: 4. Genetic Classification of Landforms
docs.text:
This modern classification focuses on the Origin (Genesis) of the landform:

  1. Tectonic Landforms: Formed by plate movements (Fault scarps).
  2. Fluvial Landforms: Formed by running water (V-shaped valleys).
  3. Glacial Landforms: Formed by ice (U-shaped valleys).
  4. Aeolian Landforms: Formed by wind (Barchans).
  5. Karst Landforms: Formed by the dissolution of soluble rocks like limestone (Sinkholes, Stalactites).

docs.title: Multiple Choice Questions
docs.text:
1. Which of the following is a "First Order" landform? Click to show Answer Correct Answer: Eurasia (Continental Platform)

  2. A "Delta" is an example of which type of landform? Click to show Answer Correct Answer: Third Order / Depositional Landform

  3. Landforms predominantly shaped by folding and faulting are called: Click to show Answer Correct Answer: Structural Landforms

  4. "Mushroom Rocks" are typically found in which geomorphic environment? Click to show Answer Correct Answer: Aeolian (Wind)

  5. Which order of landforms takes the longest time to form? Click to show Answer Correct Answer: First Order

docs.title: Descriptive Questions
docs.text:
1. Why are mountains considered "Second Order" landforms? Click to see Key Points

    • They are regional features found on continents.
    • They are created by large-scale endogenetic forces (tectonics).
    • They provide the structural template for third-order landforms.

  2. Distinguish between Erosional and Depositional landforms. Click to see Key Points

    • Erosional: Result from the removal of rock material (e.g., a valley).
    • Depositional: Result from the accumulation of sediment (e.g., a sand dune).

docs.title: Weathering, Mass Wasting, and Erosion: Denudational Processes
1. Introduction: The Process of Denudation
docs.text:
Denudation is a general term that includes all exogenetic processes which wear away the Earth's surface and reduce its elevation. It involves a sequence of three major sub-processes:

  1. Weathering: The in-situ breakdown of rocks.
  2. Mass Wasting: The movement of materials downslope under gravity.
  3. Erosion: The removal and transportation of rock fragments.

docs.title: 2. Weathering (In-Situ Breakdown)
docs.text: Weathering is the mechanical or chemical alteration of rocks without movement.

docs.title: A. Physical (Mechanical) Weathering
docs.text:
Breakdown into smaller pieces without changing mineral composition.

  • Frost Wedging: Water enters cracks, freezes, expands (9%), and shatters rock. Common in high altitudes.
  • Thermal Expansion (Exfoliation): Repeated heating (day) and cooling (night) cause rocks to peel like an onion.
  • Salt Wedging: Growth of salt crystals in arid regions exerts pressure on rocks.

docs.title: B. Chemical Weathering
docs.text:
Decomposition of rocks through chemical changes.

  • Oxidation: Reaction of minerals with oxygen (e.g., "rusting" of iron-rich rocks).
  • Carbonation: Carbonic acid (rainwater + CO2) dissolves rock, especially limestone, creating caves.
  • Hydration: Absorption of water by minerals, causing them to expand and weaken.

docs.title: C. Biological Weathering
docs.text:
Weathering caused by living organisms.

  • Roots: Tree roots grow into joints and force them apart.
  • Animal Activity: Burrowing animals (rabbits, worms) expose fresh rock to the elements.
  • Lichen/Algae: Produce acids that slowly dissolve the rock surface.

docs.title: 3. Mass Wasting (Gravity in Action)
docs.text: Mass wasting is the downslope movement of soil, regolith, and rock under the direct influence of Gravity. It is distinguished from erosion because it does not require a transporting medium (like a river).

docs.title: Classification of Mass Wasting
docs.text:
• Creep: Extremely slow, imperceptible movement. Evidence: tilted fences and curved tree trunks.
  • Slump: Downward slipping of a mass of rock moving as a unit along a curved surface.
  • Rockfall: Vertical move of free-falling rock fragments.
  • Flows: Material containing a large amount of water moves as a viscous fluid (e.g., Mudflows).

docs.title: 4. Erosion vs. Weathering
docs.text:
While both break down the Earth's surface, they are distinct:

Feature Weathering Erosion Movement In-situ (no movement) Dynamic (involves transport) Agent Atmosphere/Climate Water, Wind, Ice, Waves Target Rock outcrops Loose sediment and rock Result Regolith/Soil formation Landform creation (Valleys, Peaks)

docs.title: Multiple Choice Questions
docs.text:
1. Which process is characterized by rock breaking into "onion-like" layers? Click to show Answer Correct Answer: Exfoliation (Thermal Expansion)

  2. The formation of "Rust" on rocks is an example of: Click to show Answer Correct Answer: Oxidation (Chemical Weathering)

  3. Curved tree trunks on a slope are a sign of which mass wasting process? Click to show Answer Correct Answer: Soil Creep

  4. Which rock type is most susceptible to "Carbonation"? Click to show Answer Correct Answer: Limestone

  5. Wait is the primary distinction between Mass Wasting and Erosion? Click to show Answer Correct Answer: Mass Wasting relies solely on gravity; Erosion requires a transporting agent.

docs.title: Descriptive Questions
docs.text:
1. How does frost wedging lead to rock disintegration? Click to see Key Points

    • Water enters rock joints.
    • It freezes at night or in winter.
    • Ice expands by 9% in volume.
    • This expansion exerts internal pressure that eventually shatters the rock.

  2. Describe two types of Chemical Weathering. Click to see Key Points

    • Oxidation: Minerals reacting with oxygen to form oxides (weakens the rock).
    • Carbonation: Acidic rainwater reacting with carbonates (e.g., limestone) to form soluble bicarbonates.

docs.title: Introduction
docs.text:
While Unit I focused on foundations, Unit II shifts the focus to long-term change. Landscape evolution is not a static state but a continuous, dynamic process. This unit explores the systematic mechanisms of landform progression through critical phases: Erosion (Degradation), Transport, and Deposition (Aggradation). It also emphasizes the role of environmental stressors and the geological framework in shaping the Earth's topography.

Fig 1: The Landscape Evolution Cycle - Processes of Degradation, Transport, and Aggradation.

docs.title: Learning Objectives
docs.text:
By the end of this unit, you should be able to:

  1. Map the Cycle: detailed understanding of the Disaster Management Cycle and its phases.
  2. Plan Effective Responses: Identify critical activities required before, during, and after a disaster.
  3. Empower Communities: Understand the bottom-up approach of Community Based Disaster Preparedness (CBDP).
  4. Know the Stakeholders: Recognize the specific roles and mandates of key agencies like NDMA, NDRF, OSDMA, and NGOs.

docs.title: Unit Outline
docs.text:
• Pre-disaster Planning: Readiness, risk assessment, and early warning.
  • During Disaster Management: Emergency response, SAR, and relief.
  • Post-disaster Planning and Development: Recovery, reconstruction, and "Building Back Better".
  • Community Based Disaster Preparedness: Strengthening the first responders.
  • Role of Stakeholders: Institutional frameworks (NGO, GO, NDMA, NIDM, NDRF, ODRAF, OSDMA).

Reference Document

Familiarize yourself with the National Disaster Management Plan (NDMP) to understand the national framework.

docs.title: Community Based Disaster Preparedness
docs.text: Community Based Disaster Management (CBDM) is an approach that promotes the involvement of the community in disaster risk management.

docs.title: Why Community?
docs.text:
Hyogo Framework for Action: Identified community participation as a key priority.

  • Local Knowledge: Communities know their own vulnerabilities.
  • First Responders: Neighbors help neighbors.

docs.title: 1. Community Risk Assessment
docs.text:
• Participatory Rural Appraisal (PRA): Tools used to map hazards.
  • Link: CBDM Manual by NIDM

docs.title: 2. Task Forces & VDMCs
docs.text:
• Village Disaster Management Committee (VDMC): The local body responsible for planning.
  • Task Forces: Search & Rescue, First Aid, Shelter Management.

Fig 1: Structure of a Community Based Disaster Preparedness Team.

docs.title: 3. Mock Drills & Awareness
docs.text:
• Regular practice is essential.
  • Resource: Do's and Don'ts by NDMA

docs.title: Case Studies
docs.text:
• Cyclone Shelters in Bangladesh & India: The management of cyclone shelters by local communities has drastically reduced death tolls.
  • Article: Community Resilience in Coastal Odisha

docs.title: Multiple Choice Questions
docs.text:
1. In Disaster Management, who are considered the "First Responders"? Click to show Options a) The National Army b) The Community members c) The Police Force d) International NGOs Click to show Answer Correct Answer: b) The Community members

  2. CBDM stands for: Click to show Options a) Central Bureau of Disaster Management b) Community Based Disaster Management c) Common Building Design Manual d) Coastal Belt Disaster Mitigation Click to show Answer Correct Answer: b) Community Based Disaster Management

  3. PRA, a tool used for community risk assessment, stands for: Click to show Options a) Public Rescue Action b) Participatory Rural Appraisal c) Primary Risk Assessment d) Public Relief Agency Click to show Answer Correct Answer: b) Participatory Rural Appraisal

  4. The "Hyogo Framework for Action" highlighted the importance of: Click to show Options a) Nuclear proliferation. b) Community participation in DRR. c) Space exploration. d) Deep sea mining. Click to show Answer Correct Answer: b) Community participation in DRR.

  5. Which of the following is NOT a typical Village Task Force? Click to show Options a) Search and Rescue Team b) First Aid Team c) Shelter Management Team d) Missile Launch Team Click to show Answer Correct Answer: d) Missile Launch Team

  6. VDMC stands for: Click to show Options a) Village Disaster Management Committee b) Virtual Disaster Monitoring Center c) Very Dangerous Monsoon Cyclone d) Volunteer Doctors Medical Corps Click to show Answer Correct Answer: a) Village Disaster Management Committee

  7. Why is "Local Knowledge" important in CBDM? Click to show Options a) It is cheaper than scientific data. b) Locals know distinct historical patterns and vulnerabilities of their area. c) It replaces the need for government help. d) It is the only way to predict earthquakes. Click to show Answer Correct Answer: b) Locals know distinct historical patterns and vulnerabilities of their area.

  8. The safety action "Drop, Cover, and Hold On" is specific to: Click to show Options a) Floods b) Earthquakes c) Cyclones d) Fires Click to show Answer Correct Answer: b) Earthquakes

  9. Who manages Cyclone Shelters in the CBDM model? Click to show Options a) The Prime Minister b) The Shelter Management Committee (local community) c) The District Collector only d) Private security firms Click to show Answer Correct Answer: b) The Shelter Management Committee (local community)

  10. Community preparedness ensures that: Click to show Options a) Disasters never happen. b) The impact of disasters is reduced through timely local action. c) The government doesn't need to do anything. d) Everyone becomes a doctor. Click to show Answer Correct Answer: b) The impact of disasters is reduced through timely local action.

docs.title: Descriptive Questions
docs.text:
1. Why is the community considering the most critical stakeholder in disaster management? Click to see Key Points

    • Proximity: They are always present when the event strikes.
    • Response Time: External help takes time (gap period); the community acts within minutes.
    • Knowledge: They understand the local terrain and high-risk households better than outsiders.

  2. Listing three common Task Forces formed at the village level and their functions. Click to see Key Points

    • Early Warning Team: Listens to radio/news and spreads alerts (megaphones/sirens).
    • Search & Rescue Team: Trained to rescue people from debris or water.
    • First Aid Team: Provides initial medical care before doctors arrive.
    • (Optional) Shelter Management Team: Maintains hygiene and food in shelters.

docs.title: During Disaster Management (Response)
docs.text: This phase, also known as the Response phase, occurs immediately after a disaster strikes.

docs.title: 1. Warning and Evacuation
docs.text:
• Disseminating immediate alerts.
  • Case Study: The successful evacuation of over 1 million people during Cyclone Phailin (2013) in Odisha is a global benchmark.
  • Article: UN Praise for Odisha's Phailin Response

docs.title: 2. Search and Rescue (SAR)
docs.text:
• Deployment of specialized forces (NDRF, ODRAF).
  • Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs): Every operation follows a strict SOP defined by the NDMA Guidelines on Incident Response System (IRS).

docs.title: 3. First Aid and Medical Care
docs.text:
• Providing immediate assistance.
  • Link: Red Cross India - Disaster Response

Fig 1: Triage Protocol for Mass Casualty Incidents.

docs.title: 4. Relief Operations
docs.text:
• Relief Camps, Food, Water, Sanitation.
  • Sphere Standards: Humanitarian response is often guided by the Sphere Standards.
  • Link: The Sphere Handbook

docs.title: Institutional Response
docs.text:
• National Crisis Management Committee (NCMC): Reviews the situation at the national level.
  • State Executive Committee (SEC): Coordinates at the state level.

docs.title: Multiple Choice Questions
docs.text:
1. The "During Disaster" phase is commonly referred to as the ______ phase. Click to show Options a) Mitigation b) Response c) Recovery d) Preparation Click to show Answer Correct Answer: b) Response

  2. The "Golden Hour" in disaster response refers to: Click to show Options a) The hour before the disaster strikes. b) The first hour after the disaster when medical aid is most critical. c) The time when the sun rises. d) The annual meeting of the NDMA. Click to show Answer Correct Answer: b) The first hour after the disaster when medical aid is most critical.

  3. Which cyclone in Odisha (2013) saw the successful evacuation of over 1 million people? Click to show Options a) Amphan b) Fani c) Phailin d) Hudhud Click to show Answer Correct Answer: c) Phailin

  4. IRS Guidelines typically refer to: Click to show Options a) Internal Revenue Service b) Incident Response System c) International Rescue Standard d) Indian Railway Safety Click to show Answer Correct Answer: b) Incident Response System

  5. "Sphere Standards" are a set of international principles for: Click to show Options a) Building roads. b) Humanitarian response (Water, Food, Shelter quality). c) Measuring earthquake magnitude. d) Satellite launching. Click to show Answer Correct Answer: b) Humanitarian response (Water, Food, Shelter quality).

  6. Who reviews the disaster situation at the National level during a crisis? Click to show Options a) NCMC (National Crisis Management Committee) b) NASA c) The State Governor d) The Local Sarpanch Click to show Answer Correct Answer: a) NCMC (National Crisis Management Committee)

  7. In Triage, priority is given to: Click to show Options a) The deceased. b) Those with minor injuries. c) Those with life-threatening but treatable injuries. d) Those who are uninjured. Click to show Answer Correct Answer: c) Those with life-threatening but treatable injuries.

  8. SAR stands for: Click to show Options a) Storage and Recovery b) Search and Rescue c) Safety and Rehabilitation d) System and Response Click to show Answer Correct Answer: b) Search and Rescue

  9. Which committee coordinates response at the State level? Click to show Options a) NCMC b) SEC (State Executive Committee) c) VDMC d) UNICEF Click to show Answer Correct Answer: b) SEC (State Executive Committee)

  10. The immediate goal of Relief Operations is to: Click to show Options a) Rebuild all houses permanently. b) Meet basic human needs (Food, Water, Shelter). c) Start new businesses. d) Improve the economy. Click to show Answer Correct Answer: b) Meet basic human needs (Food, Water, Shelter).

docs.title: Descriptive Questions
docs.text:
1. Describe the key activities undertaken during the "Response" phase of a disaster. Click to see Key Points

    • Evacuation: Moving people to safety.
    • SAR: Rescuing trapped individuals.
    • First Aid: Providing emergency medical care.
    • Relief: Providing food, clean water, and temporary shelter.
    • Communication: Restoring lines to coordinate efforts.

  2. What is the Incident Response System (IRS) and why is it important? Click to see Key Points

    • Definition: A standardized organizational structure for managing emergency response.
    • Importance: It ensures unity of command, clear roles and responsibilities, and effective coordination between different agencies (Police, Fire, Hospitals) to avoid chaos.

docs.title: Post-Disaster Planning and Development
docs.text: The post-disaster phase focuses on recovery, rehabilitation, and reconstruction.

docs.title: 1. Rehabilitation (Short to Medium Term)
docs.text:
• Restoration of essential services.
  • Post-Disaster Needs Assessment (PDNA): A standard methodology used by the UN, World Bank, and EU to assess damage and recovery needs.
  • Guide: PDNA Guidelines Vol. A

docs.title: 2. Reconstruction (Long Term)
docs.text:
• Build Back Better (BBB): The use of the recovery, rehabilitation and reconstruction phases after a disaster to increase the resilience of nations and communities through integrating disaster risk reduction measures into the restoration of physical infrastructure and societal systems.
  • Source: Sendai Framework Definition of BBB

Fig 1: The Concept of Building Back Better (BBB).

docs.title: 3. Development
docs.text:
• Disasters often open a window of opportunity for development reforms.
  • Gujarat Earthquake (2001): The reconstruction program led to a complete overhaul of the state's infrastructure and disaster management laws (GSDMA Act 2003).

docs.title: Related Articles
docs.text:
• Odisha's Recovery: How Odisha rebuilt after the 1999 Super Cyclone.
  • Article: From Despair to Model of Management (World Bank)

docs.title: Multiple Choice Questions
docs.text:
1. Rehabilitation typically refers to the ______ term recovery. Click to show Options a) Short to Medium b) Very Long c) Pre-disaster d) Immediate (Minutes) Click to show Answer Correct Answer: a) Short to Medium

  2. "Build Back Better" (BBB) aims to: Click to show Options a) Rebuild exactly as it was before. b) Use cheaper materials to save money. c) Increase resilience and reduce future risk during reconstruction. d) Rebuild only government offices. Click to show Answer Correct Answer: c) Increase resilience and reduce future risk during reconstruction.

  3. PDNA stands for: Click to show Options a) Pre-Disaster Needs Assessment b) Post-Disaster Needs Assessment c) Public Disaster Notification Authority d) Primary District National Assessment Click to show Answer Correct Answer: b) Post-Disaster Needs Assessment

  4. The reconstruction after which 2001 event is cited as a major development opportunity in India? Click to show Options a) Indian Ocean Tsunami b) Gujarat (Bhuj) Earthquake c) Kashmir Floods d) Latur Earthquake Click to show Answer Correct Answer: b) Gujarat (Bhuj) Earthquake

  5. Reconstruction is distinct from Rehabilitation because it focuses on: Click to show Options a) Temporary shelters. b) First Aid. c) Permanent repair and long-term rebuilding. d) Food distribution. Click to show Answer Correct Answer: c) Permanent repair and long-term rebuilding.

  6. Providing psychological counseling to trauma victims is part of: Click to show Options a) Mitigation b) Rehabilitation (psycho-social support) c) Prevention d) Warning Dissemination Click to show Answer Correct Answer: b) Rehabilitation (psycho-social support)

  7. Restoring electricity and water supply immediately after a storm is considered: Click to show Options a) Restoration of Essential Services b) Long-term Development c) Mitigation d) Preparedness Click to show Answer Correct Answer: a) Restoration of Essential Services

  8. The International bodies that standardized PDNA include: Click to show Options a) FIFA and IOC b) UN, World Bank, and EU c) NASA and ISRO d) Facebook and Google Click to show Answer Correct Answer: b) UN, World Bank, and EU

  9. Odisha established OSDMA following which major disaster? Click to show Options a) 2001 Earthquake b) 1999 Super Cyclone c) 2004 Tsunami d) 2013 Phailin Click to show Answer Correct Answer: b) 1999 Super Cyclone

  10. "Cash for Work" programs are often used during: Click to show Options a) Pre-disaster planning b) Early recovery/Rehabilitation stages to restore livelihoods c) Search and Rescue d) Hazard Mapping Click to show Answer Correct Answer: b) Early recovery/Rehabilitation stages to restore livelihoods

docs.title: Descriptive Questions
docs.text:
1. Differentiate between Rehabilitation and Reconstruction. Click to see Key Points

    • Rehabilitation: Short/Medium term. Focus on restoring normalcy, essential services (water/power), and temporary housing.
    • Reconstruction: Long term. Focus on permanent rebuilding of infrastructure, housing, and economy, ideally better than before.

  2. Explain the principle of "Build Back Better". Click to see Key Points

    • It is a recovery approach that doesn't just restore what was there.
    • It uses the reconstruction phase to integrate Disaster Risk Reduction (DRR).
    • Example: Relocating a school to higher ground or using earthquake-resistant technology when rebuilding a collapsed school.

docs.title: Pre-Disaster Planning
docs.text: Pre-disaster planning is the phase where actions are taken before a disaster strikes to ensure readiness.

docs.title: 1. Risk Assessment and Monitoring
docs.text:
• Hazard Mapping: Identifying potential hazards in an area.
  • Early Warning Systems (EWS):
  • Example: IMD's SATARK system in Odisha regarding cyclones.
  • Link: Indian Tsunami Early Warning Centre (ITEWC)

Fig 1: Components of an End-to-End Early Warning System.

docs.title: 2. Prevention and Mitigation
docs.text:
• Implementing long-term measures (e.g., NCRMP - National Cyclone Risk Mitigation Project).
  • Link: NCRMP Official Site

docs.title: 3. Preparedness
docs.text:
Preparedness involves building the capacity to respond effectively.

UNDRR Definition: "The knowledge and capacities developed by governments, response and recovery organizations, communities and individuals to effectively anticipate, respond to, and recover from, the impacts of likely, imminent or current hazard events or conditions." Source: UNDRR Terminology

  • Contingency Planning: Developing specific plans (e.g., District Disaster Management Plans - DDMPs).
  • Mock Drills: Conducting mock drills (e.g., annual nationwide drills by NDRF).

docs.title: Related Articles
docs.text: • Disaster Preparedness in India: An overview by the World Bank. Link: World Bank on India's DRM

docs.title: Multiple Choice Questions
docs.text:
1. What is the primary goal of Pre-Disaster Planning? Click to show Options a) To clean up debris. b) To ensure readiness and reduce risk. c) To provide compensation. d) To count the dead. Click to show Answer Correct Answer: b) To ensure readiness and reduce risk.

  2. "Hazard Mapping" is a part of: Click to show Options a) Risk Assessment b) Post-disaster recovery c) First Aid d) Search and Rescue Click to show Answer Correct Answer: a) Risk Assessment

  3. SATARK is an Early Warning System used primarily for: Click to show Options a) Earthquakes in Nepal b) Cyclones and floods in Odisha c) Droughts in Rajasthan d) Snowstorms in Kashmir Click to show Answer Correct Answer: b) Cyclones and floods in Odisha

  4. NCRMP stands for: Click to show Options a) National Cyclone Risk Management Program b) National Cyclone Risk Mitigation Project c) National Crisis Response Management Plan d) New Cyclone Relief for Many People Click to show Answer Correct Answer: b) National Cyclone Risk Mitigation Project

  5. Which of the following is an example of "Preparedness"? Click to show Options a) Building a dam. b) Stockpiling food and conducting mock drills. c) Vaccinating children. d) Providing ex-gratia to victims. Click to show Answer Correct Answer: b) Stockpiling food and conducting mock drills.

  6. Who is responsible for issuing Tsunami warnings in India? Click to show Options a) ISRO b) ITEWC (INCOIS) c) WHO d) IIT Delhi Click to show Answer Correct Answer: b) ITEWC (INCOIS)

  7. A "Contingency Plan" is best described as: Click to show Options a) A plan for economic development. b) A specific plan for a potential future emergency event. c) A historical record of past disasters. d) A building layout. Click to show Answer Correct Answer: b) A specific plan for a potential future emergency event.

  8. The main purpose of a "Mock Drill" is to: Click to show Options a) To scare the public. b) To test the readiness and effectiveness of response plans. c) To waste resources. d) To generate media publicity. Click to show Answer Correct Answer: b) Test the readiness and effectiveness of response plans.

  9. Early Warning Systems (EWS) are most effective when: Click to show Options a) They are kept secret. b) They reach the last mile (the most vulnerable community). c) They are only in English. d) They are issued after the event. Click to show Answer Correct Answer: b) They reach the last mile (the most vulnerable community).

  10. DDMP stands for: Click to show Options a) District Disaster Management Plan b) Daily Disaster Management Protocol c) Department of Disaster Mitigation Planning d) Delhi Disaster Management Program Click to show Answer Correct Answer: a) District Disaster Management Plan

docs.title: Descriptive Questions
docs.text:
1. What are the key components of Pre-Disaster Planning? Click to see Key Points

    • Risk Assessment: Hazard mapping and vulnerability analysis.
    • Prevention & Mitigation: Structural (dams) and non-structural (laws) measures.
    • Preparedness: EWS, contingency planning, resource stockpiling, and training/drills.

  2. Why are Early Warning Systems (EWS) critical in disaster management? Click to see Key Points

    • They provide lead time to take action (evacuation).
    • They significantly reduce loss of life (e.g., Cyclone Phailin vs 1999 Super Cyclone).
    • They protect livelihoods by allowing people to secure assets.

docs.title: Unit II: Self Assessment & Questions
docs.text: Test your understanding of the concepts covered in Unit II (DM Cycle, Preparedness, Response, Recovery, and Stakeholders).

docs.title: Multiple Choice Questions (MCQs)
docs.text: 1. Which phase of the Disaster Management Cycle includes "Search and Rescue" operations? Click to show Options A) Pre-Disaster B) During Disaster (Response) C) Post-Disaster (Recovery) D) Mitigation Click to show Answer Correct Answer: B) During Disaster (Response)  2. The apex body for Disaster Management in India, headed by the Prime Minister, is: Click to show Options A) NIDM B) NDRF C) NDMA D) OSDMA Click to show Answer Correct Answer: C) NDMA (National Disaster Management Authority)  3. What does the acronym "NDRF" stand for? Click to show Options A) National Disaster Relief Fund B) National Disaster Response Force C) National Disaster Rescue Force D) National District Response Force Click to show Answer Correct Answer: B) National Disaster Response Force  4. Conducting "Mock Drills" is a part of which phase? Click to show Options A) Rehabilitation B) Preparedness C) Reconstruction D) Relief Click to show Answer Correct Answer: B) Preparedness  5. The concept of "Build Back Better" is primarily associated with which phase? Click to show Options A) Early Warning B) Response C) Reconstruction & Recovery D) Evacuation Click to show Answer Correct Answer: C) Reconstruction & Recovery  6. Which state in India was the first to establish a State Disaster Management Authority (OSDMA)? Click to show Options A) Gujarat B) Maharashtra C) Odisha D) Kerala Click to show Answer Correct Answer: C) Odisha  7. What is the primary role of NIDM (National Institute of Disaster Management)? Click to show Options A) Search and Rescue B) Funding Relief Operations C) Capacity Building and Human Resource Development D) Declaring disasters Click to show Answer Correct Answer: C) Capacity Building and Human Resource Development  8. In "Community Based Disaster Preparedness", who are considered the first responders? Click to show Options A) The Army B) The Police C) The Community members D) International NGOs Click to show Answer Correct Answer: C) The Community members  9. Rapid Damage Assessment is typically conducted in which phase? Click to show Options A) Mitigation B) Immediate Post-Disaster (Response/Early Recovery) C) Pre-Disaster D) Long-term Development Click to show Answer Correct Answer: B) Immediate Post-Disaster (Response/Early Recovery)  10. Which of the following is NOT a role of NGOs in disaster management? Click to show Options A) Mobilizing community resources B) Providing government policy approval C) Specialized relief services (medical, food) D) Advocacy for vulnerable groups Click to show Answer Correct Answer: B) Providing government policy approval (This is a government function)

docs.title: Descriptive Questions
docs.text: 1. Describe the Disaster Management Cycle and briefly explain the activities involved in Pre-disaster, During-disaster, and Post-disaster phases. (click to see key points) Click to see Key Points Key Points: - Cycle: A continuous process. - Pre-disaster: Prevention, Mitigation, Preparedness (Risk assessment, Early Warning). - During-disaster: Response (Search & Rescue, First Aid, Relief). - Post-disaster: Recovery, Rehabilitation, Reconstruction (Build Back Better).  2. Discuss the role of the National Disaster Response Force (NDRF) and Odisha Disaster Rapid Action Force (ODRAF) in disaster management. (click to see key points) Click to see Key Points Key Points: - NDRF: Specialized national force, highly trained for diverse disasters (CBRN, floods, collapse), rapid deployment. - ODRAF: Specialized state force (Odisha), focus on cyclones/floods, road clearance, immediate rescue. - ODRAF: Specialized state force (Odisha), focus on cyclones/floods, road clearance, immediate rescue. - Coordination: Both work in coordination with local authorities and communities.

docs.title: Role of Stakeholders in Disaster Management
docs.text:
Disaster management is a multi-disciplinary effort.

Fig 1: Institutional Framework for Disaster Management in India.

docs.title: 1. National Disaster Management Authority (NDMA)
docs.text:
• Official Website: ndma.gov.in
  • Role: Apex body headed by the Prime Minister. Policies, plans, and guidelines.
  • Mandate: DM Act 2005.

docs.title: 2. National Institute of Disaster Management (NIDM)
docs.text:
• Official Website: nidm.gov.in
  • Role: Capacity building, training, research, and documentation.
  • Publications: Produces training modules and case studies.

docs.title: 3. National Disaster Response Force (NDRF)
docs.text:
• Official Website: ndrf.gov.in
  • Role: Specialized force for specialized response.
  • Motto: "Aapda Seva Sadaiv Sarvatra" (Disaster Service Always Everywhere).

docs.title: 4. Odisha State Disaster Management Authority (OSDMA)
docs.text:
• Official Website: osdma.org
  • Role: The first dedicated disaster management authority in India (est. 1999).
  • Achievements: Received the Subhash Chandra Bose Aapda Prabandhan Puraskar for excellence in disaster management.

docs.title: 5. Odisha Disaster Rapid Action Force (ODRAF)
docs.text:
• Role: Specialized state force for search and rescue.
  • Structure: Units are stationed across the state for rapid deployment.

docs.title: 6. NGOs and International Bodies
docs.text:
• UNDRR: undrr.org - Global policy and framework (Sendai).
  • Red Cross: icrc.org - Humanitarian aid.
  • Article: Role of NGOs in Disaster Management

docs.title: Multiple Choice Questions
docs.text:
1. Who is the Ex-officio Chairperson of the NDMA? Click to show Options a) The President of India b) The Prime Minister of India c) The Home Minister d) The Chief Justice Click to show Answer Correct Answer: b) The Prime Minister of India

  2. The primary mandate of NIDM is: Click to show Options a) To fight fires. b) To provide funds to states. c) Capacity building, training, and research. d) To arrest looters. Click to show Answer Correct Answer: c) Capacity building, training, and research.

  3. ODRAF is a specialized force belonging to which state? Click to show Options a) Andhra Pradesh b) West Bengal c) Odisha d) Tamil Nadu Click to show Answer Correct Answer: c) Odisha

  4. NDMA gets its powers from which Act? Click to show Options a) The Constitution of India b) The Disaster Management Act, 2005 c) The Epidemic Act, 1897 d) The Police Act, 1861 Click to show Answer Correct Answer: b) The Disaster Management Act, 2005

  5. NGOs primarily work at which level of disaster management? Click to show Options a) Policy making in Parliament b) Grassroots level with communities c) Military deployment d) Space monitoring Click to show Answer Correct Answer: b) Grassroots level with communities

  6. OSDMA was adjudged the best in India for disaster management, receiving which award? Click to show Options a) Bharat Ratna b) Subhash Chandra Bose Aapda Prabandhan Puraskar c) Padma Bhushan d) Ashok Chakra Click to show Answer Correct Answer: b) Subhash Chandra Bose Aapda Prabandhan Puraskar

  7. The motto of NDRF includes: Click to show Options a) Satyameva Jayate b) Service Before Self c) Aapda Seva Sadaiv Sarvatra d) Valour and Wisdom Click to show Answer Correct Answer: c) Aapda Seva Sadaiv Sarvatra

  8. UNDRR primarily deals with: Click to show Options a) Conducting elections. b) Disaster Risk Reduction at the global level. c) Selling insurance. d) Building bridges. Click to show Answer Correct Answer: b) Disaster Risk Reduction at the global level.

  9. Who is responsible for Disaster Management at the District level? Click to show Options a) The MLA b) The District Collector/Magistrate (DDMA) c) The Police Commissioner only d) The Chief Minister Click to show Answer Correct Answer: b) The District Collector/Magistrate (DDMA)

  10. The Red Cross is famous for its role in: Click to show Options a) Humanitarian aid and relief. b) Starting wars. c) Building nuclear reactors. d) Stock market trading. Click to show Answer Correct Answer: a) Humanitarian aid and relief.

docs.title: Descriptive Questions
docs.text:
1. Discuss the role of the National Disaster Management Authority (NDMA). Click to see Key Points

    • Apex Body: Headed by the PM.
    • Policy: Lays down policies, plans, and guidelines for DM.
    • Coordination: Ensures enforcement and implementation of the DM Act.
    • Funding: Recommends provision of funds for mitigation.

  2. Briefly explain the significance of the Odisha State Disaster Management Authority (OSDMA). Click to see Key Points

    • Pioneer: First dedicated SDMA in India (set up after the 1999 Super Cyclone).
    • Success: Transformed Odisha from a disaster-vulnerable state to a model of resilience (e.g., Phailin evacuation).
    • Innovation: Built multipurpose cyclone shelters and set up ODRAF and SATARK.
